title: 106_hr3843
content: The "Small Business Reauthorization Act of 2000" reauthorizes small business programs. The Small Business Act is amended to authorize program levels for fiscal year 2001, including technical assistance grants and direct loans. Additionally, deferred participation loans and other financings are authorized for a total sum, with specific allocations for general business. The Small Business Act is amended to authorize program levels for fiscal year 2001, including various loans and financings totaling $22.7 billion for different business programs. This includes general business loans, financings, loans for specific sections, purchases of participating securities, and guarantees. The Small Business Act authorizes guarantees of debentures, grants, and cooperative agreements for various programs totaling $22.7 billion for fiscal year 2001. This includes guarantees not exceeding $4 billion for Small Business Investment Act programs and $5 million for the Service Corps of Retired Executives program. Additionally, $14 million is authorized for direct appropriations to the Administration. For fiscal year 2001, the Small Business Act authorizes $14 million for direct administration of loan programs and $10 million for Investment Division salaries and expenses. Additionally, necessary funds are authorized for administrative expenses, loan capital for disaster loans, and other provisions of the Act. For fiscal year 2001, the Small Business Act authorizes funds for direct administration of loan programs, Investment Division salaries, administrative expenses, and disaster loans under section 7(b) and title IV of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. No funds are authorized for the loan program under section 7(a)(21) unless transferred from another Federal department, and the Administration is restricted from approving loans without full funding for general business loans. The Small Business Act authorizes funds for loan programs and administrative expenses. The Administration can approve loans under specific conditions, with a limit of $1,250,000 for gross amounts in fiscal year 2002. The Small Business Act authorizes funds for loan programs and administrative expenses. The Administration is authorized to make $20,250,000,000 in deferred participation loans and other financings for various programs under the Act. This includes $15,000,000,000 in general business loans, $4,500,000,000 in financings, $500,000,000 in loans, and $80,000,000 in direct loans. The Administration is authorized to make $3,500,000,000 in purchases of participating securities and $2,500,000,000 in guarantees of debentures under title III of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. Additionally, guarantees not to exceed $5,000,000,000 are authorized for programs under part B of title IV, with a limit of $650,000,000 for bonds approved pursuant to section 411(a)(3) of the Act. The Administration is authorized to make grants or enter cooperative agreements for a total amount of $6,000,000 for the Service Corps of Retired Executives program. Additionally, there are authorizations for appropriations totaling $27,000,000 for loan programs and salaries/expenses related to the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. In fiscal year 2002, funds are authorized for the Administration under title II of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 for administrative expenses, necessary loan capital for disaster loans, and title IV expenses. No funds are authorized for the loan program in that year. The Administration is authorized to provide loan capital for the loan program under section 7(a)(21) only through transfer from another Federal department or agency, unless the program level for general business loans is fully funded. The Administration cannot approve loans on its own behalf or on behalf of any other Federal department or agency under terms other than those authorized by law. In fiscal year 2003, the Administration is authorized to provide $90,000,000 in technical assistance grants and $100,000,000 in direct loans under section 7(m) of the Act. Additionally, $21,800,000,000 in deferred participation loans and other financings are authorized for programs under the Act. In fiscal year 2003, the Administration is authorized to provide $16,000,000,000 in general business loans, $5,000,000,000 in financings, $500,000,000 in loans, $300,000,000 in loans, $4,000,000,000 in purchases of participating securities, and $3,000,000,000 in guarantees for programs under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. In fiscal year 2003, the Administration is authorized to provide $16,000,000,000 in general business loans, $5,000,000,000 in financings, $500,000,000 in loans, $300,000,000 in loans, $4,000,000,000 in purchases of participating securities, $3,000,000,000 in guarantees of debentures, and $7,000,000 for the Service Corps of Retired Executives program. In fiscal year 2003, the Administration is authorized to provide $17,000,000 for loan programs under sections 7(a) and 7(m) of this Act, $12,000,000 for the Investment Division, and additional funds for administrative expenses and necessary loan capital. In fiscal year 2003, the Administration is authorized to provide $17,000,000 for loan programs under sections 7(a) and 7(m) of this Act, $12,000,000 for the Investment Division, and additional funds for administrative expenses and necessary loan capital for disaster loans pursuant to section 7(b), and to carry out title IV of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958, including salaries and expenses of the Administration. The Administration is authorized to approve loans under specific terms and conditions, with a maximum amount of $1,250,000 under section 7(a)(21) of the Act. SEC. 3. ADDITIONAL REAUTHORIZATIONS. The text chunk discusses amendments to various programs under the Small Business Act, including increased funding for the Small Business Development Centers Program and changes to the Drug-Free Workplace Program and HUBZone Program for fiscal years 2001 through 2003. Additionally, authorization of appropriations for the Women's Business Enterprise Development Programs is mentioned. The Women's Business Ownership Act is amended to increase funding from $600,000 to $1,000,000 for fiscal years 2001 through 2003. Amendments are also made to the Very Small Business Concerns Program and the Socially and Economically Disadvantaged Businesses Program, extending the deadline to September 30, 2003. SEC. 4. LOAN APPLICATION PROCESSING. The Administrator of the Small Business Administration will conduct a study to determine the average processing time for loan applications under the Small Business Act. Results of the study will be transmitted to Congress within 1 year.
